comment_body.0: Not a what car should I buy thing, but has anyone thought about bringing the stupid questions Wednesday" thread back once a week? I was really saddend when they stopped with those threads as they brought so much new information to so many people
comment_body.1: What 2020/20201 sedans or hatches in the US have a tow rating? Accord doesn't, Civic Doesn't, Corolla doesn't, Camry doesn't, Mazda 3 doesn't. Everyone has removed their tow ratings over the last generation or two.
comment_body.2: I have a question about a specific car I’m looking at. I’m looking at a Toyota Camry as a commuter. It sounds like the car was taken care of pretty well. However, the previous owner says that the cylinder head was shaved because his mechanic was worried it wouldn’t pass smog. Is that concerning? To me, it’s a red flag. Maybe there was another reason the mechanic was worried it wouldn’t pass smog. A Camry wouldn’t suddenly not pass smog unless something else was wrong, right? I kind of wanted something stock, but maybe I’m overreacting.
comment_body.3: Does 3 years in a model make a big difference? Deciding between a 2018 M3 and 2015 M3, and the 2015 M3 only has 12K miles and is $10K cheaper than the 2018M3, so wondering if 3 years makes a difference at all?
comment_body.4:
Hello. I'm 15 and I'm doing research for my first car in advance. I want a sedan that had a little bit of upgrade potential, but is also a great car stock. It could be super slow for all I care, as long as it has good enough handling. Im ok with going over my budget for something more reliable. Id prefer to have leather seats and the ability to upgrade to a stereo with android auto. I want to work on the car myself, and a manual transmission is a must. I'm currently considering an Audi A4 b5 1.8t.

• Location: northeast Ohio

• Price range: under 5k, but I'm flexible

• Lease or Buy: buy

New or used: used

• Type of vehicle: sedan

• Must haves: Good handling, leather seats, ability to upgrade to android auto

• Desired transmission: manual

• Intended use: daily driver

· Vehicles you've already considered: Audi a4 b5 1.8t, nb miata

· Is this your 1st vehicle: yes

• Do you need a Warranty: no

• Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: im definitely willing to learn

• Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: no

comment_body.24:
ATTN: already know which car, looking for advice on buying a new car from a dealership. Things you regret getting/not from the dealership, hindsight is 20/20 kind of things. Jump to the end in "additional notes" for the real Q's

  • Location: Ohio, USA

  • Price range: $30-$39k

  • Lease or Buy: Buy; financing. Never gone through a dealer before though, always paid cash for my used cars.

  • New or used: New cuz I'm boujee and this is my reward to myself. Cars don't depreciate if you never plan on selling them. Plan to finance until I own, get onto a 2yr rotating lease for a daily, and turn this into my weekend car

  • Type of vehicle: FR, lightweight, drivers car. BRZ/86 is that ideal car.

  • Must haves: RWD, manual trans, feels good to drive but doesn't need to be straight line fast.

  • Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): manual, unless it's cheap enough to buy auto that I can afford to drop a new 6 speed into it

  • Intended use: Daily with light mods for 5 years, then weekend/track/rally car

  • Vehicles you've already considered: Toyota 86 - Hakone was the dream but there are no manuals left in the USA...

  • Is this your 1st vehicle: No

  • Do you need a Warranty: Yes?

  • Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Novice but yes and want to learn using this car

  • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: Eventually? Dad used to rebuild muscle cars, he's not super comfortable on the new electronics, but I work with it code and hardware for a living so feel like we can bridge the gap

Additional Notes: What are things you would do over when buying a new car? I won't be able to place my build order until spring most likely so I'm trying to figure out all of the "hidden" costs and stuff that isn't built into the MSRP. The add-ons I want, the ones that aren't worth it and to avoid, etc.

Any dealership specific additions I should avoid or look into more? I've never bought through a dealership and I know they will throw a gauntlet of packages at you. I know the damage ones *can* be worth it if they cover enough, but can also be a PITA with a bad dealer. Anything else they might be able to offer that is worth looking at? Any obvious "scam" packages to avoid like the plague? What about any immediate aftermarket things to look at like undercoatings/etc?
comment_body.25: Ok so I am trying to get into cars and I don't know how and also wanted to know what good engines can I put inside of a Toyota gt-86 for drifting and what other modification can I do
comment_body.26:
Location: Chester County, PA

Price range: 30k through low 40k’s

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Sport SUV

Must haves: Must fit a rear facing car seat in the back. Apple Car Play. Leather interior. AWD.

Desired transmission: Auto

Intended use: Daily use and shuttling a baby and chocolate lab around.

Vehicles you've already considered: Audi Q5/SQ5 (possibly too small), BMW X5, Jaguar F-Pace, Jeep Grand Cherokee.

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Ideally CPO, but not a deal breaker if not.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

I’ve driven an Infiniti G37xS sedan since 2016 and have loved it. My wife and I had our first kid about 6 months ago, but the presence of a car seat has made the front of the car pretty cramped. Additionally, we have to take 2 cars if we ever want to travel with both our daughter and our 10 year old chocolate lab, which is a pain.

Ideally, I’d prefer to pick up an SUV that offers the same type of sporty driving experience as my G37xS, but a more luxurious and less-sporty ride is ok too. Thinking ahead, we plan on having a second kid in a few years and would need to comfortably fit a second car seat in the back.

I love the look of the Q5/SQ5, but I have my doubts about interior cargo space. I’m not entirely opposed to the Grand Cherokee, but it definitely doesn’t check the “sporty” box, which is a big “want” for me. If I were to go with the JGC, I’d most likely be going with the Overland trim. I love the BMW X5, but the typical “BMW’s aren’t reliable” stigma has me spooked.

Apple CarPlay is a big “want” for me as well, which means a 2017 X5 (or newer), 2018 Q5/SQ5 (or newer) and a 2018 JGC (or newer). Not super high on doing an aftermarket stereo mod for Apple CarPlay integration, but have done it before.

Any help or recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
comment_body.27:
Hi guys, it's me again - the one who's hungry for a nice, manual sports car.

So, the SW20 MR2 has been a dream car of mine for as long as I can remember. I think its perfect - T-top, POP UP HEADLIGHTS, how it looks, etc. As such, I am now looking for one.

Trouble is, prices of it are steadily increasing (still haven't caught on as much as Supras or GTRs, but there's an uptick) and I think this won't come back down.

So this is my dilemma: go for one now, it's a bit pricy to finance but I can achieve one of my dreams or just forget about it? I would really love one, and the one thing that I don't want to feel 5, 10 years down the line is "fuck I should've bought it when it was cheaper, now it's out of range".

It's a Rev 3, turbo, 245 Hp, LSD, manual, the works. Well-maintained. Looks fantastic. Fuck yeah or hell naw?

*Also if any of you have similar stories, please share! Thanks :)

Location: Chicago area, USA

Price range: $2,000-$4,000

Buy, used

Type of vehicle doesn’t matter; no must-haves other than working air conditioning and heating.

Automatic transmission.

Not my first vehicle, but I can’t do any minor or major work on it.

I’m thinking something like a used Honda or Toyota car? But my main goal is something reliable, that’ll last a few years of light use without costing a lot in repairs.

This will be used for errands and emergencies. My wife and I are moving out of the city (where we often didn’t even need one car) to the suburbs. She’ll be taking our current car to and from work; I usually work remotely and just need one to get around a little bit — errands, the golf course, etc. Cheap and easy to maintain are the goals here — I’m not a car guy, I just want something that’ll prevent me from feeling cut off once we’re out of the city and I can’t walk everywhere anymore.

We’re probably four years or so from buying a new car with cash (just have some other financial priorities first, and tbh this is not a need per se), and I just need something that’ll last me until then, at which point my wife gets the new car and I get our current car.

What would be a cheap, reliable option that would last me a few years?

comment_body.39: Trying to decide between a 4Runner TRD Off Road and a Wrangler Unlimited Rubicon as my next car. I had leased a Wrangler a few years ago when I was in school and absolutely loved it. Gave it back since I was moving to NYC and had no need for a car. Now I'm out in the suburbs again and need a daily to commute to the train station in the morning but also go on weekend adventures. Like I said, I'm used to a Wrangler and am comfortable with its quirks and have no problem spending the cash on the Rubicon. I test drove a 4Runner the other day and really liked it as well. It's significantly cheaper than the Wrangler and my family has a long history with the Toyota dealer so they're giving me a great deal. Any current/previous Wrangler/4Runner owners care to weigh in and let me know if there's anything else I should consider? Thanks everyone!

Lease or Buy: buy

New or used: used

Type of vehicle: hatchback/wagon

Must haves: manual transmission, reliable, somewhat fun to drive, 4-doors a plus but not essential

Vehicles you've already considered: mazda3, civic si, matrix xrs, golf/jetta tdi, tdi sportwagen, audi a3. I previously had a mk6 gti and would love another but I think they're out of my price range and I'm not sure I trust the TSI engine. There's also an mk4 R32 with a 220k mile body/78k engine for sale near me for $11k if I wanted to splurge.

I found a '05 civic si (I know the EP3 is the worst si) with 80k miles that looks well taken care of with all maintenance records from a private seller out of state for $5400 and an '02 XRS from a dealer with 120k miles for the same price. I've been on the hunt for a mazda3 but haven't found a manual without rust issues. I like the idea of a bulletproof diesel engine but the VWs/Audi TDI seem to be higher priced and I think they'd be more expensive to maintain, so I'm not sure they're worth the extra cost. Must haves: We are a no kids family, the reason we are looking at SUV is to be able to transport gear and stuff, we like to do outdoor stuff and want to be able to thorw in a bunch of camping gear or a bike, maybe mount a kayak to the roof... stuff like that.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): auto

Intended use: daily driver

Vehicles you've already considered: Really open to anything

Is this your 1st vehicle: No, previously owned a prius and a PT Cruiser

Do you need a Warranty: open to it

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: At this point I am just getting started in my research, so im looking for a general direction to look in and suggestions on a good SUV you think fits for two people in there 30s. We have no kids and a dog. I want something I can drive for the next 10+ years and will hold up to Minnesota winters.

Thanks in advance for taking the time to respond.
comment_body.53:
Hi all, hope everyone reading this is doing well today!

As of next week I'll be looking to secure a deposit on my first car, heading out for a test drive at the weekend.

(30 year old looking to finally explore the country, so not in the mindset I was at 18 or I'd be buying a banger for sure!)

I'm looking at a 2014 onwards 118D, possible MSport but not dependent on that, but I am looking for SatNav.

My budget is around £9500 (I work in car finance so getting it sorted via that route) which means I'm really looking at 60-70k miles - these two have my eye right now:

https://www.autotrader.co.uk/car-details/202009053368182?onesearchad=New&onesearchad=Nearly%20New&onesearchad=Used&aggregatedTrim=118d&postcode=s459pw&radius=45&price-to=9500&year-from=2014&advertising-location=at_cars&model=1%20SERIES&make=BMW&sort=mileage&page=1

autotrader.co.uk/car-details/202010215262065?onesearchad=New&onesearchad=Nearly%20New&onesearchad=Used&aggregatedTrim=118d&postcode=s459pw&radius=45&price-to=9500&year-from=2014&advertising-location=at_cars&model=1%20SERIES&make=BMW&sort=mileage&page=1

Now I'm not experienced with cars, and I would really like to avoid serious faults down the line. The first one comes with an RAC check and the second one service history/MOT pass last month.

I guess I'm just looking for someone to point out if there would be anything glaringly wrong that I'm missing, or anything in particular that I need to be looking at? I'll be requesting copies of the service histories on both cars so that I can have a look at everything that has recently gone wrong or been replaced etc.

Thanks!

​

$5600-$7100; negotiated from $5000 to $4700).

comment_body.60:
Hi there, someone hit my car this weekend and I need to start looking at a new one as it’s most likely totaled. I would love some advice into where to even begin looking for styles/reliable brands I like. My mom has always been the big car researcher in our family and Im not sure if she’s got horrible luck or horrible research skills because everyone in my family have ALWAYS had major manufacturing-type car troubles lol. This will be my first car purchase and I want to (hopefully) avoid the same mistake!!

Location: Central TX, USA or Birmingham, AL (I switch back and forth so both places are car buying options for me)

Price range: $17000 max, I would like a payment <$250/month after $5000 down

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: I like compact SUVs a lot, that’s where my heart is leaning

Must haves: Reliability really. I want to feel confident that my car isn’t going to need to go to the shop every 4 months. I also would like good gas mileage but reliability is #1 for sure.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): No preference

Intended use: Daily Driver, nothing special :)

Vehicles you've already considered: I had a 2012 Nissan rogue and even though it had lots of expensive transmission/oil cooler issues, I still loved the look of the car. I also like Jukes, Honda CRV’s (my top pick probably), and cars like the subaru forester.

Is this your 1st vehicle: No, but it is the first one I will be purchasing myself

Do you need a Warranty: It would be really nice to have one but it’s not essential

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No but I know a pretty good/cheap mechanic

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: Thank you so much for your help. I’m open to even general stuff like reliable car brands or even reliable sales companies. People in my family have had a jeep patriot, honda pilot, nissan rogue, and VW bug (this one was really old and cheap though) in the last 8 years and they were all bought used. Every single one of those had major transmission issues or they flooded because they were built wrong or electrical issues or something. Maybe we just have horrible luck or we buy from bad used car places, but I don’t want to make the same mistake!

Any advice helps, I’m a complete novice who’s pretty young and nervous so I would appreciate anything, even smalls “rules of thumb” to keep in mind :)

comment_body.62:
Location: PNW, US

Price range: ~$60000

Lease or Buy: either

New or used: new

Type of vehicle: car

Must haves: Good looking

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): prefer auto

Intended use: Daily Driver

Vehicles you've already considered: See additional notes

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Yes

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:

I'm looking for a comfortable daily driver in the coming year. I came from B9 A4, to M340i, and currently on a FK8 type R. A4 was nice, then as my lease ends, I wanted something cooler so got the M340i. but then feels like it was too similar to an regular 3 series despite having great power. the interior is literally the same, not even having additional carbon fiber trim or different seats. I was not happy with paying extra $100 (compares to an A4) for it.

Later I jumped on manual hype train and got the civic type r. It looks so good in my eye even after half year of usage. However, I start to feel the road/wind noise are too high for my taste, and i'd prefer a more comfortable ride. I realized i'm not as hard core sports car fun as I thought I'd be, and It's be better for me to have a dedicated fun car for weekend once I can afford it.

right now I'm looking to replace my type r in the upcoming year once COVID situation is under control. I'm looking for a car that looks good inside and out in it's price range, preferably not as common on the road. Ride well, quiet on highway cruise speed and with ACC to handle stop and go traffic. On top of that, having nice exhaust sound/V6 would be great as this could be my last ICE car considering the trend.

Cars I've considered:

Upcoming:

2022 Stinger GT. Good looking exterior, alright interior, relatively cheap compares to other V6 options, current gen praised for being a great GT car. But no digital cluster, and interior quality could be subpar compares to other traditional luxury brand.

2022 CT4-V blackwing. rumored with 450HP, cool digital cluster and other leaked interior bits. But small center screen, exterior backend looks weird.

2022 Audi RS3. Great and unique 5 pot sound, fast in straight line, high tech interior feeling. But could have too much plastic judging from current S3 interior, and exterior somewhat conservative compares to other high performance model.

Available now:

CLA45. Great looking inside out. But sound not as good and feel bad having a 4 pot in this price range.

Audi S5. Great looking outside, OK interior mostly because of the central screen looks a bit after thought. Great trunk space being a hatch. But sound and accelaration not as good compares to other options in the price range, more depreciation as an in between trim.

2021 C43. Decent looking inside out, last model year before refresh. Great 6 pot sound. But lots of bad story regarding the overall quality for this car which is built in the US. such as rim, transmission issue etc. Jerky shifting and stiff ride.

logically stinger looks like the way to go. being 20-30% cheaper comparing to other options. On the other hand, I don't consider myself as someone who cares about the badge of the car, but somehow other cars in the list just feel more exciting to me. It could just be the fact that other in the list are more exclusive, unique though. Having a hard time to decide, would love some feedbacks
